adjective.description: Relating to the body as opposed to the mind.
examples: a whole range of physical and mental challenges

adjective.description: Relating to things perceived through the senses as opposed to the mind; tangible or concrete.
examples: physical assets such as houses or cars

adjective.description: Relating to physics or the operation of natural forces generally.

noun.description: A medical examination to determine a person's bodily fitness.

phrases: They fought over the controller for a good 20 minutes until their mom's had to separate them because they were getting physical.
They even joked about what would happen if their competition got physical.
Or maybe it was fortunate for Bryant that he's smart enough to let words fuel the fire and not get physical with Shaq.
It got physical soon enough and I watched him beat my mother ruthlessly.
The newspaper followed up on the death of a black club patron who was suffocated by a white bouncer when a dispute over the club's dress code got physical.
origin: Late Middle English (in the sense relating to medicine): from medieval Latin physicalis, from Latin physica things relating to nature (see physic). Sense 2 dates from the late 16th century and sense 1 from the late 18th century.
